([[Secretary of State for the Colonies]]) | follows = [[1894 Colonial Conference]] | precedes = [[1902 Colonial Conference]] | website = | keypoints = Imperial council, imperial defence }} The '''Colonial Conference of 1897''' was a conference between the [[Secretary of State for the Colonies]] and the 11 [[self-governing colony|self-governing]] [[British colony|colonies]] of the [[British Empire]]. The conference was convened in London by Colonial Secretary [[Joseph Chamberlain]] in 1897 on the occasion of Diamond Jubilee of [[Queen Victoria]]. Chamberlain's intention was to draw the self-governing colonies into closer co-operation with the United Kingdom. Delegates were sent to the conference by Canada, [[Newfoundland Colony]], New Zealand the Australian self-governing colonies of [[New South Wales]], [[Queensland]], [[South Australia]], [[Tasmania]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and [[Western Australia]], and the South African colonies of [[British Cape Colony|Cape Colony]] and the [[Colony of Natal]]. Chamberlain proposed the creation of a permanent Imperial Council made up of delegates from the colonies to act as an Empire-wide parliament with the power to bind the colonies on imperial matters but this was rejected by the colonies due to fears of loss of autonomy. Chamberlain also propose that colonies increase their contributions to the [[Royal Navy]] but only some colonies agreed to increase their contributions and no permanent arrangement was agreed to.{{cite book|title=Historical dictionary of European imperialism|year=1991|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=0313262578|pages=136–137|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uyqepNdgUWkC}} Chamberlain also proposed a [[customs union]] between the colonies and Britain while Canada proposed [[Imperial preference|preferential trade]] but no decision was made by the delegates.{{cite news|title=Colonial Conference|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qxsRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JZUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6172,322193&dq=colonial+conference&hl=en|accessdate=27 December 2014|newspaper=Sydney Mail|date=10 July 1897|publisher=news.google.com}}{{cite book|title=Historical dictionary of European imperialism|year=1991|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=0313262578|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uyqepNdgUWkC|page=138|accessdate=27 December 2014}} ==Participants== The conference was hosted by [[Queen Victoria]], with her Colonial Secretary and the Premiers of various colonies: {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Infobox Muslim scholar | era = [[Islamic golden age]] | name = Ahmad Ibn Yahya al-Baladhuri | title= al-Baladhuri | birth_date = | death_date = 278-279 AH/892 CE<ref>Translation of Futuh al-Buldan by Hitti</ref><ref name="Britannica">{{EB1911|inline=1|wstitle=Balādhurī|volume=3|page=233}}</ref> | Maddhab = | school_tradition= | ethnicity = | region = [[Iraq]] | main_interests = [[History]] | notable_ideas= | works = <small>[[Kitab Futuh al-Buldan]] and [[Ansab al-Ashraf]]</small> | influences = | influenced = }}
'''ʾAḥmad Ibn Yaḥyā al-Balādhurī''' ({{lang-ar|أحمد بن يحيى بن جابر البلاذري}}) was a 9th-century Muslim historian. One of the eminent [[Middle Eastern]] historians of his age, he spent most of his life in [[Baghdad]] and enjoyed great influence at the court of the caliph [[al-Mutawakkil]]. He traveled in [[Syria]] and [[Iraq]], compiling information for his major works.
His full name was Ahmad Bin Yahya Bin Jabir Al-Baladhuri ({{lang-ar|أحمد بن يحيى بن جابر البلاذري}}), Balazry Ahmad Bin Yahya Bin Jabir Abul Hasan<ref name="salaam.co.uk">[http://www.salaam.co.uk/knowledge/biography/viewentry.php?id=460 Salaam Knowledge<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> or Abi al-Hassan Baladhuri.<ref>[http://www.answering-ansar.org/answers/fadak/en/chap2.php Answering-Ansar.org :: Fadak; The property of Fatima al-Zahra [as]<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070125224232/http://www.answering-ansar.org/answers/fadak/en/chap2.php |date=2007-01-25 }}</ref>
==Biography== Al-Baladhuri's ethnicity has been described as [[Arab people|Arab]]<ref name="AdelElmi2013" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bosworth|first1=C. E.|title=BALĀḎORĪ|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/baladori-abul-hasan|publisher=ENCYCLOPÆDIA IRANICA|accessdate=22 November 2016}}</ref> and [[Persian people|Persian]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Saunders|first1=J.J.|title=A history of Medieval Islam|date=2006|publisher=Routledge|location=London [u.a.]|isbn=0-415-05914-3|page=58|edition=Reprint.|quote=Baladhuri was probably of Persian origin: he lived and wrote in Baghdad, and died in 892.}}</ref><ref name="AdelElmi2013">{{cite book|author1=Gholamali Haddad Adel|author2=Mohammad Jafar Elmi|author3=Hassan Taromi-Rad|title=Historians of the Islamic World: Selected Entries from Encyclopaedia of the World of Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3CAYThJIQUgC&pg=PA2|date=31 January 2013|publisher=EWI Press|isbn=978-1-908433-12-1|pages=2–}}</ref> although his sympathies seem to have been strongly with the Arabs, for [[Masudi]] refers to one of his works in which he rejects Baladhuri's condemnation of non-Arab nationalism [[Shu'ubiyya]].<ref name="Britannica"/>
He lived at the court of the [[caliph]]s [[al-Mutawakkil]] and [[Al-Musta'in]] and was tutor to the son of [[al-Mutazz]]. He died in 892 as the result of a drug called ''[[baladhur]]'' (hence his name).<ref name="Britannica"/> (''Baladhur'' is ''Semecarpus anacardium'', known as the "marking nut"; medieval Arabic and Jewish writers describe it as a memory-enhancer).<ref name="Bos">[https://www.jstor.org/stable/619709 Bos, Gerrit: " 'Baladhur' (Marking-Nut): A Popular Medieval Drug for Strengthening Memory", ''Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies'', University of London, Vol. 59, No. 2 (1996), pp. 229-236] (full-text via JSTOR; article's first page available for all)</ref>
==Works== {{wikisource author}} His chief extant work, a condensation of a longer history, ''[[Kitab Futuh al-Buldan]]'' (فتوح البلدان), "Book of the Conquests of Lands", translated by [[Phillip Hitti]] (1916) and [[Francis Clark Murgotten]] (1924) in ''The Origins of the Islamic State'', tells of the wars and conquests of the Arabs from the 7th century, and the terms made with the residents of the conquered territories. It covers the conquests of lands from Arabia west to Egypt, North Africa, and Spain and east to Iraq, Iran, and Sind.
His history, in turn, was much used by later writers. ''[[Ansab al-Ashraf]]'' (أنساب الأشراف, “Lineage of the Nobles”), also extant, is a biographical work in genealogical order devoted to the Arab aristocracy, from Muhammad and his contemporaries to the Umayyad and Abbāsid caliphs. It contains histories of the reigns of rulers.<ref>"Balādhurī, al-." ''Encyclopædia Britannica'' 2006.</ref>
His discussions of the rise and fall of powerful dynasties provide a political moral. His commentaries on methodology are sparse, other than assertions of accuracy.<ref>http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t125/e283?_hi=5&_pos=1</ref>

{{Orphan|date=January 2015}}
'''Alberto Iria''' (1909 in [[Olhão]], [[Algarve]], [[Portugal]] – 1992 in [[Paço de Arcos]] near [[Lisbon]], Portugal) was a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[historian]].
After school in [[Faro, Portugal|Faro]] he studied history, philosophy, literature and library sciences at [[University of Lisbon]] and at [[University of Coimbra]] and finished 1936 with thesis about the history of the French Invasion by General [[Andoche Junot]] in Algarve in 1808. Thereafter he did work in the archives of the Ministry of Finance and in the National Library.
From 1946 bis 1975 he headed the Colonial Archives ([[Arquivo Histórico Ultramarino|Historical Overseas Archives]]), together with The Ministry of Finance he organized some anniversary exhibitions and festivals. Finally he became a member of Lisbon Academy of Sciences and in 1984 also vice-president of The National Academy of History.
Iria was "commander" of the [[Order of the Southern Cross]] and a specialist for the history of his [[Algarve]] home region.

{{Use British English|date=May 2014}} [[File:Broadwater Farm Riot, Day 2, 004sm.jpg|thumb|400px|Broadwater Farm riot: the next day]] The '''Broadwater Farm [[riot]]''' occurred around the [[Broadwater Farm|Broadwater Farm estates]] area of [[Tottenham]], [[North London]], on 6 October 1985.
The events of the day were dominated by two deaths. The first was that of Cynthia Jarrett, an [[British African-Caribbean community|African-Caribbean]] woman who died the previous day due to [[heart failure]] during a police search at her home. It was one of the main triggers of the riot in a context where tension between local black youth and the largely white [[Metropolitan Police]] was already high due to a combination of local issues and the aftermath of [[Brixton riot (1985)|another riot]] which had occurred in the [[Brixton]] area of London the previous week following the shooting of a black woman ([[Cherry Groce|Dorothy 'Cherry' Groce]]) during another police search.<ref name=BBC2540397>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/september/28/newsid_2540000/2540397.stm|title=1985: Riots in Brixton after police shooting|publisher=BBC News|date=28 September 1985|accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=GuardArch85Brix>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2009/sep/30/brixton-riots-1985-archive|title=From the archive: Riots in Brixton after police shooting|author=Gareth Parry, Susan Tirbutt and David Rose|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 September 1985|accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=BBC28248588>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-28248588|title=Police blamed over 1985 Cherry Groce Brixton shooting|publisher=BBC News|date=10 July 2014|accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=BBC28248588/><ref name=BBC2486315>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/october/1/newsid_2486000/2486315.stm|title=1985: Riots erupt in Toxteth and Peckham|publisher=BBC News|date=1 October 1985|accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref> In July 2014, the [[Metropolitan Police Commissioner]], Sir [[Bernard Hogan-Howe]], apologised "unreservedly" for the shooting and the time it had taken to say "sorry" following an inquest into the death of Dorothy "Cherry" Groce, whose shooting by the Metropolitan Police triggered the riots. The jury inquest blamed the Metropolitan Police for failures that contributed to Groce's death.<ref name=BBC28248588/><ref name=BBC28248588/><ref name=BBC2486315/> The second death was that of [[Police Constable|PC]] [[Keith Blakelock]], the first police officer since 1833 to be killed in a riot in Britain.<ref>[[Kenneth Newman|Newman, K.]] [http://www.police-foundation.org.uk/files/POLICE0001/speeches/1986%20Sir%20Kenneth%20Newman.pdf ''Police-Public Relations: The Pace of Change: Police Foundation Lecture 1986''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721071915/http://www.police-foundation.org.uk/files/POLICE0001/speeches/1986%20Sir%20Kenneth%20Newman.pdf |date=21 July 2011 }}, The [[Police Foundation]], 1986</ref>
==Death of Cynthia Jarrett== At 13:00 hrs on 5 October 1985, a young [[British African-Caribbean community|black]] man, Floyd Jarrett, who lived about a mile from the Farm, was arrested by [[Metropolitan Police Force|police]], having been stopped in a vehicle with an allegedly suspicious [[Vehicle Excise Duty|car tax disc]].<ref name="Thompson, K 1988">Thompson, K. Under siege: racial violence in Britain today (1988) Penguin Books Ltd 978-0140523911</ref> He was taken to nearby Tottenham police station and charged with theft and assault (he was later acquitted of both charges). Five and a half hours later, D.C. Randle and three other officers decided to search his mother's home, also close by. Forty-nine-year-old Mrs Jarret immediately collapsed and died from a heart attack during disputed circumstances.<ref name="Brain, T. 2010">Brain, T. (2010) A history of policing in England and Wales from 1974: a turbulent journey. Oxford University Press.</ref> During the coroner's inquest into Mrs Jarret's death, her daughter, Patricia claimed to have seen D.C. Randle push her mother whilst conducting the search inside their house, causing her to fall. Randle denied this allegation.<ref name="Thompson, K 1988"/>
Cynthia Jarrett's death sparked outrage from some members of the black community against the conduct of the [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]]. There was a widespread belief that the police were [[institutionally racist]]. A black woman, [[Cherry Groce]], had been shot by police a week earlier in Brixton. Four years earlier, the [[Scarman Report]] into the [[1981 Brixton riot]] criticised police. In particular, the local council leader, [[Bernie Grant]], later condemned the search and urged the local police chiefs to resign immediately as their behaviour had been "out of control".<ref>{{cite news|title=Policeman killed in riot|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/1985/oct/07/ukcrime.garethparry|newspaper=The Guardian|date=7 October 1985|location=London|first1=Gareth|last1=Parry|first2=Andrew|last2=Rawnsley|first3=John|last3=Ezard}}</ref>
==Day of disturbances== There was a demonstration the following day outside Tottenham [[police station]] by a small crowd of people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930184655/http://www.met.police.uk/history/broadwater_farm.htm|title=Metropolitan Police Service - History of the Metropolitan Police Service|date=30 September 2007|publisher=}}</ref> Violence between police and youths escalated during the day. [[Riot control|Riot police]] tried to clear streets using [[baton charge]]s. The youths in the conflict used bricks and [[petrol bomb]]s. The evening TV news claimed there were shots at the police, two officers, PC Stuart Patt, another unnamed officer, being treated for gunshot wounds. Three journalists (Press Association reporter Peter Woodman, BBC sound recordist Robin Green, and cameraman Keith Skinner) were also claimed to have been hit. Cars were set on fire and barricades made. The main conflict took place on the estate itself, with police officers and rioters injured and dozens of rioters arrested.
==Murder of PC Blakelock== {{main|Murder of Keith Blakelock}}
At 9.30pm, Police and London Fire Brigade responded to reports of a fire on the elevated level of Tangmere House; this block consisted of a shopping level with flats and maisonettes above. The location itself was some distance away from the main body of rioting, and as such was being policed by units who were less well-equipped and -prepared in terms of disorder training. The [[London Fire Brigade]] came under attack as did the 'serial' of police, including Blakelock, who were there to assist. The rioting was too intense for police not trained in riot control and they and the firefighters withdrew, chased by rioters. Blakelock tripped, fell, and was surrounded by a mob with [[machete]]s, [[knife|knives]] and other weapons, who killed him in an attempt to decapitate him. PC Richard Coombes suffered a serious facial injury from one of the attackers when he made efforts to rescue his colleague. The rioting tailed off during the night as rain fell and news of the death spread.
==Aftermath== Police maintained a substantial presence on the estate for several months, arresting and questioning 400 people. The disturbances led to changes in police tactics and equipment, and efforts to re-engage with the community. [[Bernie Grant]], then leader of the Labour-controlled Haringey Council, later elected as Labour MP for Tottenham, was widely condemned for reportedly saying, "the police got a bloody good hiding" (although the actual statement was "the youth think they gave the police a bloody good hiding.")<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2000/may/25/uk.labour|title=Politics, race and the fight to inherit|newspaper=The Guardian|date=25 May 2000|accessdate=17 February 2018}}</ref>
Afterwards, the local council invested in the estate to improve some of the problems which were seen as factors in the rioting. By 2016 and although there is still contention with the police, the area has improved.{{cn|date=September 2016}}
The riot prompted the Metropolitan Police to devise the [[Gold-silver-bronze command structure]] for responding to sudden major incidents. Among the difficulties with the police response was that orders had to be communicated through numerous ranks, and it was never clear who was in operational charge.
==Trials== Six people (three juveniles and three adults) were charged with the murder of Blakelock. The juveniles all had their cases dismissed after the judge ruled the conditions in which they had been held were so inappropriate that their interrogation was inadmissible - conditions included being questioned naked except for a blanket, and being questioned without a guardian.<ref name="guardian.co.uk">[[The Guardian]] – [https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2004/jan/18/ukcrime.race Article of detailing trial evidence], 18 January 2004</ref>
Three adults, [[Winston Silcott]], Engin Raghip and Mark Braithwaite, were convicted of murder and sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] despite no witnesses and no forensic evidence.<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/> The Tottenham Three are Innocent Campaign and the Broadwater Farm Defence Campaign pressed for a retrial. On 25 November 1991, all three defendants were cleared by the [[Court of Appeal]] when an [[Electrostatic detection device|ESDA]] test demonstrated police notes of interrogations (the only evidence) had been tampered with.<ref name="Brain, T. 2010"/> Braithwaite and Raghip were released after four years in prison. Silcott remained in prison for the separate murder of another man, Tony Smith. He was released on licence in 2003 after serving eighteen years for that crime. The officer in charge of the interrogation was cleared of [[perjury]].
In July 2013, Nicholas Jacobs was charged with the murder of PC Blakelock. Four other men arrested at the same time were not charged.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/jul/23/keith-blakelock-murder-broadwater-farm | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Vikram | last=Dodd | title=PC Keith Blakelock: man charged with murder at Broadwater Farm riots | date=23 July 2013}}</ref> On 9 April 2014, Jacobs was cleared of all charges.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-26960690 | work=BBC News | title=PC Keith Blakelock: Nicholas Jacobs cleared of killing officer | date=9 April 2014}}</ref>
==Inquest== At the inquest into the death of Cynthia Jarrett her daughter, Patricia, alleged that her mother had been pushed over by Detective Constable Michael Randle, which he denied. The inquest found that Jarrett had died accidentally. No police officers were charged or disciplined for her death.
===Broadwater Farm memo controversy 1985===
In 1985, [[Oliver Letwin]] and [[Hartley Booth]] co-authored a memo as members of then-Prime Minister Thatcher's policy unit in response to Broadwater Farm in London urging "Thatcher to ignore reports that rioting in mainly black urban areas was the result of social deprivation and racism."<ref name="NYT_2015_12_dec" /> Broadwater Farm riot was part of a series of riots sparked by the shooting of the mother of [[Michael Groce]] — both [[Afro-Caribbean]] in a mainly Afro-Caribbean neighbourhood — by the [[Metropolitan Police]] on 28 September 1985 in the mainly Afro-Caribbean [[London Borough of Lambeth|Lambeth]] neighbourhood, sparked a [[1981 Brixton riot|second]] riot in Brixton.<ref name=BBC2540397/><ref name=GuardArch85Brix/><ref name=BBC28248588/><ref name=BBC28248588/> Over the next weeks and months riots broke out in [[Peckham]],<ref name=BBC2486315/> [[1985 Toxteth riots|Toxteth]] and at the Broadwater Farm estate in Tottenham, North London. In 1985 Letwin was then considered to be a "young star" of the Conservative Party. The memo scorned suggestions by senior cabinet ministers to set up a £10m communities programme to tackle inner-city problems by helping blacks start businesses as suggested by [[David Young, Baron Young of Graffham|David Young]], refurbishing public housing council blocks as suggested by [[Kenneth Baker, Baron Baker of Dorking|Kenneth Baker]] and "establishing training programs for low-income youth." Letwin claimed it would not ameliorate the situation but would do little more than "subsidise Rastafarian arts and crafts workshops" stating that black "entrepreneurs will set up in the disco and drug trade".<ref name="theguardian_2015_dec_30">{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/dec/30/oliver-letwin-blocked-help-for-black-youth-after-1985-riots | title=Oliver Letwin blocked help for black youth after 1985 riots: Cameron's policy chief makes apology over advice to Thatcher that assistance would benefit 'disco and drug trade' and Rastafarian crafts | publisher=The Guardian | date=30 December 2015 | accessdate=30 December 2015 | author=Travis, Alan}}</ref>
When the 1985 paper was released under the [[Thirty-year rule|30 years rule]] into the public record through the National Archives on 30 December 2015, a chastened Letwin apologised on the same day for "the offence caused".<ref name="NYT_2015_12_dec">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/31/world/europe/oliver-letwin-riots.html?_r=0 | title=Release of 1985 Race Riots Memo Prompts Apology From Cameron Aide | publisher=New York Times | date=30 December 2015 | accessdate=30 December 2015 | author=Erlanger, Steven}}</ref><ref name="theguardian_2015_dec_30" /> The memo argued that the riots were caused by bad behaviour not social conditions:
{{quote|"Lower-class, unemployed white people lived for years in appalling slums without a breakdown of public order on anything like the present scale; in the midst of the depression, people in Brixton went out, leaving their grocery money in a bag at the front door, and expecting to see groceries there when they got back...Riots, criminality and social disintegration are caused solely by individual characters and attitudes. So long as bad moral attitudes remain, all efforts to improve the inner cities will founder."|Oliver Letwin, Hartley Booth Policy Broadwater Farm memo to Prime Minister Thatcher 1985 (released to the public domain on 30 December 2015)<ref name="BBC">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-35192265 | title=Letwin apologises over 1985 Broadwater Farm riot memo | publisher=BBC | date=30 December 2015 | accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref>}}

'''Burrows Cave''' is the name given to an alleged cave site in a disputed location in Southern [[Illinois]] supposedly discovered by Russell E. Burrows. Burrows says it contained a number of artifacts. Through the many inconsistencies that evolve around Russell E. Burrows' story of discovery and its findings, the cave and its contents are considered a [[hoax]] by mainstream archaeologists and some fringe archaeologists. ==Location== During the time of the discovery, it was thought that the alleged cave must have been located in [[Richland County, Illinois|Richland County]] somewhere near the town [[Olney, Illinois]] where Burrows resided at the time. Burrows claimed that he did not want to give away the location of the cave because he believed that the cave would be robbed of its ancient treasures. ==Discovery== Burrows says he discovered the cave while hiking along the hillside miles away from the [[Ohio River]], where he later claims that he was searching for buckles from the [[American Civil War|Civil War era]] and pioneer horseshoes with his metal detector. Burrows says that he came across a hole into which he fell that led him into the mysterious cave full of priceless ancient artifacts. The cave was said to have contained numerous archaeological artifacts, including carvings, coins, and other items. Many of the purported artifacts are said to have inscriptions in various ancient languages such as [[Phoenician language|Phoenecian]] and [[Iberian language|Iberian]], but the inscriptions are generally meaningless. ==Cave as "tomb"== Burrows claims that the cave is a tomb holding the artifacts and remains of 13 crypts. To date, nobody outside Burrows's immediate circle has claimed to have been inside the cave, and many of the so-called artifacts have been revealed as forgeries. The cave and its artifacts are widely considered to be a hoax or fraud,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LDxgE6EpE8EC&pg=PA131&dq=Russell+Burrows+Hoax#v=onepage&q=Russell%20Burrows%20Hoax&f=false |title=Haunting the Prairie: A Tourists Guide to the Weird and Wild Places of Illinois|via=Google Books |publisher=Black Oak Media |date= 2010-01-01|accessdate=2014-01-20|isbn=9780979040146 |author1=Kleen |first1=Michael|page=131 }}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gE4P1bhDCB4C&pg=PA38&dq=Russell+Burrows+Hoax |title=Weird Illinois: Your Travel Guide to Illinois' Local Legends and Best Kept Secrets |author1= Troy Taylor|author2= Mark Moran|author3=Mark Sceurman |via= Google Books |publisher=Sterling Publishing Company |page=38 |accessdate=2014-01-20|isbn=9780760759431 |year=2005 }} {{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=xmDnhPNLwYwC&pg=PA49&dq=Russell+Burrows+Hoax#v=onepage&q=Russell%20Burrows%20Hoax&f=false |title=Encyclopedia of Dubious Archaeology: From Atlantis to the Walam Olum|page=49 |via=Google Books |publisher=ABC-CLIO |date= |accessdate=2014-01-20|isbn=9780313379185 |author1=Feder |first1=Kenneth L |year=2010 }}{{cite journal | last = Wilson | first = Joseph AP | authorlink = | title = The Cave Who Never Was: Outsider Archaeology and Failed Collaboration in the USA |journal = [[Public Archaeology (journal)|Public Archaeology]] | volume = 11 | issue = 2 | pages = 75–93 | year = 2012 | url = http://www.maneyonline.com/doi/ref/10.1179/1465518712Z.0000000007 | doi = 10.1179/1465518712Z.0000000007 }} even among proponents of other [[Pseudoarchaeology|pseudoarchaeological]] theories such as [[Barry Fell]].Fell, H. B. (1987). Detecting Fraudulent Inscriptions. Epigraphic Society Occasional Publications, 16: 24. [http://www.epigraphy.org/volume_16.htm] The idea has gained some traction within proponents of [[Mormon archaeology]]{{cite web|url=http://www.s8int.com/truesuppressions3.html |title=True Suppressions 3: Burrows Cave, "Newark Holy Stones, "Sopher Plates"; Fakes as Orthodox Science Claims-Or - True Suppressions? |publisher=S8int.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-21}} and [[Hyperdiffusionism in archaeology|hyperdiffusionism]] advocates such as [[Frank Collin]] (writing as Frank Joseph).{{cite web|url=http://www.ancientamerican.com/aa/index.php/book-store |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213090245/http://www.ancientamerican.com/aa/index.php/book-store |archivedate=2013-12-13 |df= }}{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=fLXtAAAAMAAJ&q=Schaffranke+iberic&dq=Schaffranke+iberic | title=Unearthing ancient America | accessdate=20 January 2014 | author=Joseph, Frank| isbn=9781601630315 | year=2009 }} ==Media== Burrows and the cave were one of the subjects of the second season "Grand Canyon Treasure" episode of ''[[America Unearthed]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/shows/america-unearthed/videos/america-unearthed-grand-canyon-treasure |title=America Unearthed: Grand Canyon Treasure Full Episode - America Unearthed |publisher=HISTORY.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-21}}{{cite web |url=http://www.jasoncolavito.com/1/post/2013/12/review-of-america-unearthed-s02e05-grand-canyon-treasure.html |title=Review of America Unearthed S02E05: "Grand Canyon Treasure" |publisher=JasonColavito.com |date=2013-12-29 |accessdate=2014-01-21}} and the show ''Holy Grail in America'', both produced by the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]]. Thomas Emerson, the Illinois state archaeologist and former head of the [[Illinois Historic Preservation Agency]] warned that the claims being made by Burrows cave proponents were sensational, and not backed by solid evidence.{{cite news | publisher=Centralia Morning Sentinel | title=Marion County to appear in America Unearthed episode | date=Dec 21, 2013 | author=Rutland, Reece}} With no evidence of the cave and its existence, many archaeologists quickly dismissed Burrows and the alleged cave. ==Phoenician ship scenario== Until about 1993, the predominant Burrows Cave scenario involved [[Phoenicia|Phoenecian]] and [[Ancient Libya|Libyan]] (North African) colonists. Part of the evidence for this involved a stone tablet supposedly depicting a Phoenician vessel. [[Frank Collin|Frank Joseph]], one of the key figures involved with the cave, reproduced this in his book ''The Lost Treasure of King Juba: The Evidence of Africans in America before Columbus'' alongside an image of an actual Phoenician vessel that had been used by an associate of Burrows who had originally identified it as Phoenician. In doing so he cropped the image from the Burrows stone making the paddle end of a steering oar unidentifiable but leaving the steering oars that are shown on what he calls (and the artist depicts) as the prow of the boat. The anthropologist and geographer [[George F. Carter]], a supporter of the concept of [[trans-cultural diffusion]], commented on the image saying
"The 'author' did not recognize the paired oars, and hung an 'impossible' oar over the bow. All others equally botched up. Fanciful stern pieces...Oar over bow - crude fakery by an ignoramus in the world of ships."{{cite journal | last = Wilson | first = Joseph AP | authorlink = | title = The Cave Who Never Was: Outsider Archaeology and Failed Collaboration in the USA |journal = [[Public Archaeology (journal)|Public Archaeology]] | volume = 11 | issue = 2 | pages = 75–93 | year = 2012 | url = http://www.maneyonline.com/doi/ref/10.1179/1465518712Z.0000000007 | doi = 10.1179/1465518712Z.0000000007 }}
==Dating== The image used to identify the ship as Phoenician actually is dated to around 700 BCE, but Joseph described it as dated 170 BCE, possibly because around this time Burrows Cave was being portrayed as the destination of [[Mauretania]]ns, including "exiled Romans, Africans, Celts, Christians and Jews"Meador, S. 2004. Untitled Review. "Rambles: A Cultural Arts Magazine", 3 January 2004 [http://www.rambles.net/joseph_kingjuba03.html] fleeing the Romans taking with them an supposed treasure belonging to King [[Juba II]]. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.flavinscorner.com/falling.htm Falling into Burrows Cave] * [http://www.flavinscorner.com/2013bc.htm 2013 Burrows Cave update] * [http://www.criticalenquiry.org/burrowscave/burrows.shtml Burrows Cave: A Modern Hoax] * [http://www.archaeologypodcastnetwork.com/archyfantasies/57 Digging {{sic|our|nolink=y|expected=out}} Burrow's Cave] {{coord|38|44|N|88|5|W|region:US-IL_scale:100000|display=title}} [[Category:Hoaxes in the United States]] [[Category:Pseudoarchaeology]] [[Category:Marion County, Illinois]] [[Category:Archaeological forgeries]] [[Category:Richland County, Illinois]] [[Category:Mormon apologetics]] [[Category:Hyperdiffusionism in archaeology]]
